Message.Title: UBS reports on DELL....
Message.Msg: UBS’s Steve Milunovich this morning reiterates a Neutral rating on Dell (DELL) while writing that his recent meetings with Dell executives, in particular Jeff Clarke, Dell’s head of global operations, suggest to him that leaving aside the PC business, Dell could surprise over the longer term based on the strength of its enterprise business. On the one hand, Dell is doing its best to make an encouraging story about future PC growth, despite the pall cast over the industry by the dour outlook from Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) last week : Management maintains that PCs will grow as the world’s middle class almost doubles by 2020. Although we are not convinced, we are impressed by Dell’s efforts to take $1bn of client cost out and by its margin advantage with 70% of PCs sold direct. However, Milunovich is more interested in what Dell’s David Johnson, head of strategy, describes as a more nimble enterprise hardware strategy: CFO Brian Gladden said his recent discussions with investors have been 75% about PCs, 15% about acquisitions, and 10% about everything else. We think investors may be underappreciating Dell’s enterprise potential. The company’s goal is to grow enterprise computing’s operating income contribution from about 43% today to 60% in F2016. Management believes the industry is at an inflection point, not just in moving to cloud computing but in pursuing a lower-cost infrastructure approach. Steve Felice, Chief Commercial Officer, said there is a change in conversations with CIOs in that they increasingly agree with Dell that more agile and modular approach is needed. In fact, he says they are concerned that Cisco, IBM, and other single-solution vendors may not give objective advice, providing an opening for Dell. David Johnson, head of Corporate Strategy, says the last 20 years were about increasing hardware efficiency, most recently through virtualization. The next step is to simplify the architecture through (1) a next-generation memory architecture Dell will begin introducing later this year, (2) multi-tenancy in clouds, and (3) mirroring public cloud with the same private cloud infrastructure, allowing workloads to move seamlessly between the two. No longer do IT departments need to size themselves for peak loads, which run 5x average loads. The new infrastructure dovetails with Dell’s efforts with respect to cloud computing, argues Milunovich: Like HP, Dell controls the server, storage, and network so it can provide a converged infrastructure box (pod). Dell will be introducing its first full- function offering in the next few months. Furthermore, it will need cloud offerings, particularly since SMB could be the cloud sweet spot. Dell expects that private cloud will dominate even SMB, however, as these firms are concerned about losing data. Consequently, most of Dell’s work will be on premise or mirroring customers’ equipment in one of Dell’s 12 data centers. Dell argues that infrastructure providers have the advantage in hybrid clouds; our guess is that selling cloud will be one of Dell’s foremost enterprise challenges. Milunovich’s stock advice is to stay away for the moment because near-term results are under pressure. But he advises to watch for “new converged infrastructure offerings” by the end of this year.
